abstracts.cdata!:
The Operations Evaluation Department
            project performance assessment rates the outcome of the
            project as satisfactory, sustainability as likely, and,
            institutional development impacts as substantial, with a
            satisfactory Bank performance, and highly satisfactory
            performance by the Borrower. The first lesson conveys it may
            be preferable, under certain circumstances, to opt for a
            simple project that focuses on the most urgent
            rehabilitation needs, rather than aim for comprehensive, but
            time-consuming alternatives. In this particular operation,
            most of the rehabilitation works were such that would both
            benefit from continued operations by a public operator, as
            well as by a private concessionaire. Second, it is advisable
            to defer large and costly investments, e.g., water, and
            wastewater treatment plants, when the potential for demand
            management alternatives to meet a city's consumption
            exist. The project rightly concentrated on resolving
            weaknesses as a cheaper way of balancing supply and demand,
            and, improving quality compared to increasing treatment
            capacity. Third, it is important to invest early in improved
            data bases, through an operation that focuses on expanded
            metering, and modernizes the public operator's
            commercial system. Ideally, a set of baseline data should be
            created prior to project inception, and performance
            indicators monitored through the project implementation
            period. Fourth, reliable regulation of both the quality, and
            service delivery of either public or private operations is
            paramount. However, the success of regulation is contingent
            upon the timely submission of accurate data from the private
            concessionaire. Given the information asymmetry inherent in
            such arrangements, it may be necessary to strengthen the
            monitoring of the concessionaire's performance,
            possibly including the commissioning of periodic consumer
            satisfaction surveys.

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Bucharest Water
            Supply Project is rated as satisfactory, sustainability as
            likely, institutional development impact as substantial,
            Bank performance as satisfactory, and borrower performance
            as satisfactory. Lessons learned from the project
            implementation include: 1) The Bank was right to resist
            engaging in the preparation of a large-scale and complex
            operation and to focus on an operation with a relatively
            simple design given that the beneficiary had no prior
            experience in the implementation of externally financed
            projects. 2) The Bank insisted on using international
            procurement although a majority of the contracts were of a
            nature and size unlikely to attract serious international
            firms. The fact is that under the international umbrella the
            bulk of contract work was provided by local contractors with
            the external firms playing a mere role of coordinator. A
            larger openness to the local contracting industry would have
            eliminated some of the difficulties faced by the project. 3)
            While promoting the involvement of private operators in the
            delivery of local utility services is a major strategic
            objective for the Bank, it must be recognized that it lacks
            the flexibility of a commercial bank and cannot easily
            respond to the changing needs of a beneficiary by adjusting
            terms and conditions of its loans.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Bucharest Water Supply
            Project's objectives will be to finance the execution
            of a three year program of investments that have been
            identified as the highest priority to: a) improve the
            reliability and quality of the water supply; b) start to
            reduce water loss; and c) strengthen the operational,
            commercial, and financial management of the Bucharest Water
            and Sewage Company (RGAB). The components of the project
            are: a) improvement of water supply reliability and quality
            through water treatment plant and pumping station
            rehabilitation, aqueduct flow control improvement, and
            reservoir upgrading and rehabilitation; b) reduction of
            water losses by primary network repair, secondary network
            rehabilitation and a metering program; and c) institutional
            strengthening of RGAB including a public awareness and water
            wastage reduction campaign, improvement of the customer
            accounts management system, training, other technical
            assistance, and implementation supervision.
